1.5. Increased capacity of BSCs for future self-sustainability through acquired skills on best practices in field of youth entrepreneurship development BSC staff successfully trained 3 2.1. Promotional campaign on program details launched # of potential beneficiaries from targeted municipalities participated on info session 150 2.2.Organized two business plan preparation trainings per year, 3 modules in 3 municipalities, each module lasts 5 days) # potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 45 (10 women) 2.3.Organized training on basic accounting and finance issues for local potential and existing entrepreneurs in 3 municipalities (3 modules, each module lasts two days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 45 (10 women) 2.4. Organized training on marketing for local potential and existing entrepreneurs in 3 municipalities (3 modules, each module lasts two days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 35 (7 women) 2.5. Organized specialized training on hospitality service improvement and rural tourism for local potential and existing entrepreneurs in 3 municipalities (each module lasts 5 days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs from 3 municipalities certified 60 (10 women) 2.6. Organized specialized training on agricultural production for local potential and existing entrepreneurs in 3 municipalities (3 modules, each module lasts 3 days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 35 (7 women) 2.7. Organized specialized training on Global Gap Standards (3 modules each module lasts 2 days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 30(5 women) 2.8. Organized specialized training on SME Management (6 modules each module lasts 5 days) # of potential and existing entrepreneurs form 3 municipalities certified 45 (7 women) 2.9.Organized Youth Leadership and Entrepreneurship Program for unemployed youth people in 3 municipalities (each module lasts 5 days) (6 modules each module lasts 2 days) # of youth from six municipalities certified 60(10 women) 2.10. Organized regional business fair # of businesses from three municipalities participate # of visitors 60 (7 women)
500 2.11. Organized participations of BCS beneficiaries on BPC under SPARK loans fund. # of business plan proved by jury 30 (6 women) 2.12. Provided technical support to SME growth in targeted municipalities # of SMEs supported through consultancy service 9 (1 women) 3.1.Developed questionnaire and conducted in three municipalities to identify business barriers, organized round tables with LED officers in three municipalities and providing technical support in implementation of local SME development strategies # of roundtable held 6

BCS staff capacity development increased
Increased opportunity for developing new and expanding existing business Thought the supported SMEs open possibility for increasing job position and employing new workers Successful matchmakings with investors, not related to SPARK guarantee fund. Business barriers identified and process of lobbying for removing started

Despite economic growth of about 3-4% p.a. over recent years and high levels of transfer payments from donors and from Kosovo nationals living abroad, the living conditions of Kosovos population have improved only marginally. With a gross domestic product (GDP) per capita of €2.721 (2012), the country remains one of the poorest in Europe. Kosovo has the weakest employment track record in Europe: the general unemployment rate has reached 48 percent while youth unemployment rate reached 53,3%. Sustainable economic development and specific actions to address the high unemployment rates, especially in the rural areas, are a priority in Kosovo. This is especially true for areas populated by minority communities, located in Eastern Kosovo, where statistics indicate even higher levels of unemployment. Adding to the problem is also the lacking of know- how and related skills in rural areas of Kosovo. In fact, Kosovo Statistics Office indicates that 90% of rural population under the age of 30 has not completed high school.Statistical Office of Kosovo.Agriculture Household Survey 2007. Available at: http://www.ks-gov.net/ESK/eng/index.php?option=com_docman&task=cat_view&gid=9&Itemid=8 Under such circumstances, vocational education of rural population and financial support that would lead to the improved competitiveness of local businesses is essential for achieving sustainable rural development and growth. The action under this proposal will respond to the needs by increasing of economic potentials of Kosovo East communities through creating favourable conditions for development and support of businesses. Areas targeted by this Action are Klokot/Kllokot, Štrpce/Shtërpcë, and Partesh/Partes municipalities. Total estimated population of these municipalities is close to 40000 people with over 70% being Serbian minority population. For minorities, virtually the only opportunities for employment are in the few socially-owned enterprises (SOEs) that are still operating, in international organisations and NGOs and, to a lesser extent, in small private enterprises. In such an economic environment, the need for assistance in the creation of employment opportunities and sustainable livelihoods is clear from the social aspect. The action under this proposal will encourage self employment trough various skills training to provide the opportunity to youth in province to have their leadership, interpersonal and entrepreneurship skills honed through different skills models. Small business in Kosovo currently lack easy access to finance at competitive rates, which acts as an obstacle to starting small firms. This is particularly true for women entrepreneurs and also youth, who often have good business ideas but fail due to lack of funding as potential entrepreneurs are not able to access commercial loans due to a lack of equity. Similarly, micro-finance institutions have not extended a significant amount in loans to minorities and they tend to concentrate on established businesses. As minorities have less access to the job market and less freedom of movement, it is necessary to assist minorities in developing the SME sector in their communities. The project builds clearly on the activities of the SPARK delivered EURED1 project in that it consolidates further the relationships developed with the Rregional Development Agency, minority communities in Kosovo East Region and local authorities. It adds further capacity building to the existing business support centres and aims to establish sustainable support to business development. This action builds upon lessons learned from the previous BSC Strpce and BSC Novo Brdo activities delivered under EURED1 and YED project in 2013, it takes some of the best and most successful parts of the past project and expands their delivery into other target regions and target beneficiaries. The initiative under this action clearly aims to inspire business development through joint efforts of BSC Strpce and BSC Novo Brdo within minority communities in Kosovo East and Center Region with focused more targeted and better quality business support service, including the provision of reliable information, market research, start-up support, incubation and product development. However, what remains to be done is to develop an entrepreneurial culture and to provide assurance of business growth.
